node.title: A question about the non-convergence of a multi-app case
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Community, I recently had a problem:
Time Step 28481, time = 11.3918, dt = 2.98023e-12
fracture0: 
fracture0: Time Step 28481, time = 11.3918, dt = 2.98023e-12
fracture0:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.007129e+08
fracture0:       0 Linear |R| = 3.007129e+08
fracture0:       1 Linear |R| = 8.206889e-01
fracture0:  1 Nonlinear |R| = 1.665936e+06
fracture0:  Solve Converged!
fracture0: Finished Solving                                                              [ 11.86 s] [ 1868 MB]
fracture0: 
fracture0: Outlier Variable Residual Norms:
fracture0:   c: 1.737291e+06
    Finished Executing MultiApps                                                         [ 11.99 s] [ 1868 MB]
  Finished Executing MultiApps                                                           [ 12.11 s] [ 1868 MB]
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 28481, time = 11.3918, dt = 1.49012e-12
fracture0: 
fracture0: Time Step 28481, time = 11.3918, dt = 1.49012e-12
fracture0:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.007129e+08
fracture0:       0 Linear |R| = 3.007129e+08
fracture0:       1 Linear |R| = 7.470535e-01
fracture0:  1 Nonlinear |R| = 3.337135e+06
fracture0:  Solve Converged!
fracture0: Finished Solving                                                              [ 11.81 s] [ 1868 MB]
fracture0: 
fracture0: Outlier Variable Residual Norms:
fracture0:   c: 3.481749e+06
    Finished Executing MultiApps                                                         [ 11.94 s] [ 1868 MB]
  Finished Executing MultiApps                                                           [ 12.07 s] [ 1868 MB]
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 28481, time = 11.3918, dt = 1e-12
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

This is a case consisting of a main-app: tensor mechanics and a sub-app: fracture phase field.
Until then the programme runs well and no sudden deformations, breaks, etc. are seen on the exodus result file. At this step it starts not converging until the step size is reduced to unacceptable and the programme terminates automatically.
One of the tensor mechanics is solved in explicit dynamics, so there is no convergence problem. And the subapp-fracture also shows successful convergence. Then at the end the output shows: Solve Did NOT Converge!
What is the reason for this? Looking forward and thank you for your help.

Hello
So because it is explicit dynamics it s accepting solutions with a reported huge residual?
What does the multiapp convergence log say?
Did you loosen the convergence criteria on either?
We need to find why it s reporting solve not converged.
Guillaume

Hello and thank you for your kind reply!

Yes, during explicit dynamics calculations, there is no coupling of known and unknown quantities, so no iterations are required and no residuals are generated.
I don't quite understand where to view this log
yes, I did try to loosen the convergence criterion for the phase field subapp:

[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full=true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type  -snes_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu vinewtonrsls'

  nl_rel_tol = 0.5
  nl_abs_tol = 0.5e-1
  l_max_its = 100
  nl_max_its = 100
[]

So the strange thing is that the main program doesn't have a convergence problem, and the output of the subroutine shows convergence
I don't quite understand where this final non-convergence output comes from
I notice that the non-convergence is associated with Outlier Variable Residual Norms, which are controlled below the order of e-3 until the non-convergence occurs,At this point, the Outlier Variable Residual Norms is 5.254716e-02. and the program chooses to reduce the step size, however, as the step size is reduced, the Outlier Variable Residual Norms grows larger and larger, until it grows to e +6 orders of magnitude, at which point the step size is reduced below the tolerance and the calculation is terminated.
So I'm wondering if I'm missing the tolerance criterion associated with Outlier Variable Residual Norms so that the program is running at the default value, and if there is indeed such a criterion, how should I set it?
Thanks again for your kind help!

Hello
Can you try tightening it?
nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
nl_abs_tol = 1e-10

with 0.5 you are barely converging anything. Probably skipping most solves due to it being detected as already converged
There is no dedicated criteria for the outlier variable norm, that s just the outlier with regards to the regular convergence criteria

Hi
I did try
nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
nl_abs_tol = 1e-10


However
Time Step 142, time = 11.3568, dt = 0.0004
 Solve Converged!
fracture0: 
fracture0: Time Step 142, time = 11.3566, dt = 0.0004
fracture0:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 6.403193e-03
fracture0:       0 Linear |R| = 6.403193e-03
fracture0:       1 Linear |R| = 3.480882e-10
fracture0:  1 Nonlinear |R| = 8.341193e-07
fracture0:       0 Linear |R| = 8.341193e-07
fracture0:       1 Linear |R| = 4.467406e-14
fracture0:  2 Nonlinear |R| = 4.199423e-10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to FACTOR_OUTMEMORY 
fracture0:  3 Nonlinear |R| = 0.000000e+00
fracture0:  Solve Converged!
fracture0: Finished Solving                                                              [ 35.86 s] [ 1885 MB]
    Finished Executing MultiApps                                                         [ 36.04 s] [ 1885 MB]
  Finished Executing MultiApps                                                           [ 36.15 s] [ 1885 MB]

Time Step 143, time = 11.3572, dt = 0.0004
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 143, time = 11.357, dt = 0.0002
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 143, time = 11.3569, dt = 0.0001
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 143, time = 11.3569, dt = 5e-05
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 143, time = 11.3568, dt = 1.25e-05
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge


It just suddenly failed, I am totally confused.
I am thinking maybe there was an error in the strain calculations or something, do you have any ideas please? Much appreciated!

This looks odd
fracture0:  2 Nonlinear |R| = 4.199423e-10
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to FACTOR_OUTMEMORY 
fracture0:  3 Nonlinear |R| = 0.000000e+00

Can you turn on catch_up in the MultiApp parameters? That will let the multiapp try again. I guess it wont work for this very time step that returns a 'converged' but it might work on other time steps.
I would also change the petsc options to the multiapp a bit to make them more robust
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift  -snes_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu NONZERO vinewtonrsls'

Hi, I followed your advice, however:

Time Step 94, time = 11.3376, dt = 0.0004
 Solve Converged!
fracture0: 
fracture0: Time Step 94, time = 11.3374, dt = 0.0004
fracture0:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 6.111548e-03

Plus I also tried turn off everything about petsc, however:

libMesh terminating:
Unrecoverable failure to converge
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 48 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------


I checked out the other discussions, but didn't seem to find any good solutions.

In the multiapp can you set nl_min_its = 4. To force it to go beyond this 0 residual iteration which I dont believe
This is really annoying, we are not getting the logs we need to see why it s failing
Can you set:
[Executioner]
  verbose = true

in both applications and in the main app
[Problem]
  verbose_multiapps = true

and
[Outputs]
  print_linear_residuals = true
  print_nonlinear_residuals = true

in both apps
also remove catch_up = true and use sub_cycle= true in the MultiApps, to see if this is more successful

Happy Chinese New Year, Guillaume! Thank you very much for your patience and help, after the Chinese New Year holiday I tried all your suggestions again, however still struggling with this issue. Therefore, I was wondering if I could bypass this convergence problem and instead use an explicit solution method to solve this problem (ref #26929 26929 ) and was wondering if you had any suggestions? Much appreciated!

Hello
You can try to use an explicit time integrator.
You ll lose the ability to run large time steps but maybe that works for you still
Guillaume

Hi
I did try an explicit time integrator
CentralDifference

however, it doesn't work, the order parameter returns zeros all the time.
You can see the details in #26929
Could you please help me? Thanks a lot!

In the above (first post) you state that the subapp fracture shows successful convergence, but in the other issue #26929 you state the phase-field fracture model is not converging. Can you please clarify?

Hi, first of all, I am very sorry for the confusion I caused. I did make a clerical error, and the "phase field not converging" in the second post actually refers to an aborted programme for unknown reasons.
BTW, I took Guillaume's @GiudGiud   advice and started yesterday to try other relatively simple explicit integrators. I found that with both the ExplicitEuler and ExplicitMidpoint integrators, the program aborts at about 3μs.
Time Step 6046, time = 3.023, dt = 0.0005
 Solve Converged!
fracture0: 
fracture0: Time Step 6046, time = 3.023, dt = 0.0005
fracture0:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 0.000000e+00
fracture0:  Solve Converged!

Time Step 6047, time = 3.0235, dt = 0.0005
 Solve Converged!
fracture0: 
fracture0: Time Step 6047, time = 3.0235, dt = 0.0005
fracture0:  0 Nonlinear |R| = 2.364981e-06
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to FACTOR_OTHER 
fracture0:  1 Nonlinear |R| = 0.000000e+00
fracture0:  Solve Converged!

Time Step 6048, time = 3.024, dt = 0.0005
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 6048, time = 3.02375, dt = 0.00025
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 6048, time = 3.02363, dt = 0.000125
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "ConstantDT", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 187 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
[c342.hpc:00450] PMIX ERROR: UNREACHABLE in file server/pmix_server.c at line 2198

At this point, the simulation is just starting, and the material goes into yielding at about this time and starts to affect the phase field equations. There may be a correlation between this, but I did not investigate further. When I tried ActuallyExplicitEuler, I monitored from the output that the program was still running well up to 6μs (when the simulation was midway through and the structure was starting to deform inhomogeneously), so I checked the output file and found that cracks were budding normally.
The problem was large and therefore slow to compute, and I waited until the next day to check its results, however found that it aborted at ~11.4μs - comparable to the abort time of the earliest problem presented in this post. I tried the calculation four times, and each time the output looked like this: the program aborts the calculation when there is no sign of it from the output.
Time Step 28821, time = 11.5284
             old time = 11.528
                   dt = 0.0004
               old dt = 0.0004

When I checked its output, I found that the result was the same as the result of this post, i.e. whether or not an explicit integrator was used did not affect whether or not the programme aborted at that point. It seems that my attempt to bypass this problem by displaying the integrator has failed, but it's a good thing that the computation has been made more efficient (down from 24 hours to 14 hours)

The mesh distortion doesn't look too bad to me, and I can't find any information on the output to solve the problem.

libMesh terminating:
Unrecoverable failure to converge
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 118 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.
------------------------------------

this isnt enough information. We need the full message. Can you use --keep-cout and --redirect-stdout to keep ALL the logs from all processes. Then please find the one that crashed and attach the full log

[Problem]
  restart_file_base = displacement_t_out_cp/LATEST  

A total of 224 (the number of processors) output files were generated in the folder stdout.processor. X , where:

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.

It doesn't look like there's any extra logging, is it a problem with my settings?

Maybe check 49 and 47 in case the rank indexing is different.
But no I don't think you're doing anything wrong. It seems to be a parallel bug and we have no information about it.
Can you try turning off transfers one by one and see if the simulation can go further ?

Yes, 47 and 49 I have also checked and there is no additional information. In fact, I checked all 224 of these files and only 48 has this extra line in it.
**libMesh terminating:
Unrecoverable failure to converge**

After turning off transfers, if you run only the phase field part, it will change nothing. And if you run only the tensor mechanics part results in no problem. Before this I also successfully reproduced the results of a CMAME paper with my setup.

The problem is essentially this: shear strain energy is generated when the cylinder collapses, transported to the phase field module leading to cracking, which further weakens the load carrying capacity, which in turn generates even more strain energy - a cycle that leads to catastrophic collapse of the cylinder.
It may be that this extreme change is what makes the calculations difficult, and once the transfers is turned off, this property will cease to exist.
I'm going to debug it via debugging  combined-dbg to see what's wrong.Do you have any suggestions, please?

Actually this tells us something.
This message is only output by these two locations
src/fe/fe_map.C:            libmesh_catch (ConvergenceFailure &)
src/geom/cell_tet4.C:  libmesh_catch (ConvergenceFailure &)

so it's an error in libmesh.
Can you share these input files and meshes?

Hi, here's my input file and the mesh is directly in there as well.
#use miug mius mm
[MultiApps]
  [fracture]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    input_files = fracture.i
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [from_c]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    from_multi_app = fracture
    variable = c
    source_variable = c
  []
  [to_shearband_driving_force]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    to_multi_app = fracture
    variable = shearband_driving_force
    source_variable = shearband_driving_force
  []
[]

[Mesh]
  allow_renumbering = false
  [TWC]
    type = AnnularMeshGenerator
    rmax = 5
    rmin = 3.5
    nt = 3200
    nr = 210
  []
[]

[Problem]
  #Note that the suffix is left off in the parameter below.
  #restart_file_base = displacement_t_out_cp/LATEST  # You may also use a specific number here
 verbose_multiapps = true
[]

[Variables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [c]
  []
  [shearband_driving_force]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [AuxKernel]
      type = MaterialRealAux
      property = local_energy_dev
    []
  []
  [vonmises]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [AuxKernel]
      type = RankTwoScalarAux
      rank_two_tensor = stress
      variable = vonmises
      scalar_type = VonMisesStress
    []
  []
  [pressure]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [AuxKernel]
      type = RankTwoScalarAux
      rank_two_tensor = stress
      variable = pressure
      scalar_type = Hydrostatic
    []
  []
  [EPS]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [AuxKernel]
      type = MaterialRealAux
      property = eqv_plastic_strain
      variable = EPS
    []
  []
  [yield_factor]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [AuxKernel]
      type = MaterialRealAux
      property = yield_factor
      variable = yield_factor
    []
  []
  [accel_x]
  []
  [vel_x]
  []
  [accel_y]
  []
  [vel_y]
  []
[]


[AuxKernels]
  [accel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_x
      displacement = disp_x
      first = false
  []
  [vel_x]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_x
      displacement = disp_x
  []
  [accel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = accel_y
      displacement = disp_y
      first = false
  []
  [vel_y]
      type = TestNewmarkTI
      variable = vel_y
      displacement = disp_y
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [DynamicTensorMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    strain = FINITE
    incremental = true
    decomposition_method = HughesWinget
  []
  [inertia_x]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_x
  []
  [inertia_y]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_y
  []   
[]

[BCs]
  [Pressure]
      [outter_surface]
          boundary = 'rmax'
          function = triangle_pulse
          displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
      []
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [triangle_pulse]
      #4Gpa=4e9n/m^2=4e9 kg/(m*s^2)=4e9 kg/(e3e12mm*mius^2)=4e3 miug/(mm*mius^2)
      type = PiecewiseLinear

[]

[]

[Executioner]

  end_time = 20
  dt = 0.0005  # local speed is 6000m/s=6000mium/mius——1e-4mius for 0.6mium

   petsc_options_value = 'lu NONZERO vinewtonrsls'

    type = CentralDifference
    solve_type = lumped
  []
[]

[Outputs]

  interval = 200
  checkpoint = true
[]

#use miug mius mm
[Mesh]
  allow_renumbering = false
  [TWC]
    type = AnnularMeshGenerator
    rmax = 5
    rmin = 3.5
    nt = 3200
    nr = 210
  []
[]

#[GlobalParams]

    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [bounds_dummy]
  []
[]

[Bounds]

    variable = bounds_dummy
    bounded_variable = c
    bound_type = lower
  []
  [upper]
    type = ConstantBoundsAux
    variable = bounds_dummy
    bounded_variable = c
    bound_type = upper
    bound_value = 1.0

[]

# [ICs]

[Kernels]

    #lumping = true

    variable = c
    f_name = F
    mob_name = L

    variable = c
    kappa_name = kappa_op
    mob_name = L
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [pfbulkmat]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'gc_prop l visco'
    prop_values = '23.090706	0.013744468	0.363785637' # *2/12 before:/8

    #16.8kj/m^2 = 16.8 1e3 N*m/m^2 = 16.8 1e3 N/m = 16.8 10e3 kg/s^2 = 16.8 miug/mius^2
    #10 mium = 1e-2 mm
    #yita~(zhang) = yita* c_a * l/gc = 0.01 mius, c_a = 2
    #yita(origin) = 0.01*gc/(c_a*l) miug/(mm * mius)
    #visco(moose) = yita(origin)/gc = yita~(zhang)/(c_a*l) = 0.5 mius/mm
  []
  [define_mobility]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'gc_prop visco'
    property_name = L
    expression = '1.0/(gc_prop * visco)'
  []
  [define_kappa]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'gc_prop l'
    property_name = kappa_op
    expression = 'gc_prop * l'#kappa = 2gc * l/c_a), c_a = 2
  []
  [local_fracture_energy]#c_a = 2, a(d) = d^2, f_frac = (1/c_a) * (gc/l) * a(d)
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = local_fracture_energy
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    material_property_names = 'gc_prop l'
    expression = '(c^2 * gc_prop)/(2 * l)'
    derivative_order = 2
  []
  [fracture_driving_energy]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables = 'c shearband_driving_force'
    material_property_names = 'local_fracture_energy(c) degradation(c)'
    expression = 'local_fracture_energy + degradation * shearband_driving_force'
    derivative_order = 2
    property_name = F
  []
  [degradation]#a1
  type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = degradation
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    expression = '((1.0-c)^2)/(((1.0-c)^2)+a1*c*(1-0.5*c))'
    constant_names       = 'a1'
    constant_expressions = '0.8'
    derivative_order = 2
  []
[]

[Executioner]
verbose=true
  type = Transient
   petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift  -snes_type'
   petsc_options_value = 'lu NONZERO vinewtonrsls'

  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = ActuallyExplicitEuler
    solve_type = lumped
  []

   nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
   nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
   l_max_its = 100
   nl_max_its = 100
[]

First of all, an update: the tensor mechanics section after turning off transmission also shows the same error at a later stage
Time Step 28994, time = 11.5976, dt = 0.0004
 Solve Converged!

Time Step 28995, time = 11.598, dt = 0.0004
 Solve Converged!

Time Step 28996, time = 11.5984, dt = 0.0004
libMesh terminating:
Unrecoverable failure to converge
[bithuangsen@ln1 only_tensor_mechanics]$ cat 2971570.err 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 48 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

The phase field part after switching off transport is not simulated as it will remain unchanged without a driving force.


The graph above shows their final outputs before and after turning off transfer. They are very close to each other, both are moments when the catastrophic collapse is about to start. Combined with your comment "it's an error in libmesh", I think the error may be caused by the mesh being about to distort. But at least looking at the final output, I can't see a big distortion, before and after turning off transfer as shown below.


I will use restart and output to the exodus file step by step starting from the approaching error instead of '''interval'''.
Also, I'll check the
src/fe/fe_map.C: libmesh_catch (ConvergenceFailure &)
src/geom/cell_tet4.C: libmesh_catch (ConvergenceFailure &)

It seems I need this object JCEOSnl and this file 0.02722-10.txt at least to run this simulation.
If you cannot share them, it would be could to create substitutes for a minimal non-working example

Sorry, it was the zip that failed to upload, it's attached now!
JCEOSnl.zip
10-0.0005-1-3.zip
Hi, at the moment of approaching the crash I went through restart and wrote the results of each step to the exodus file and found that the mesh was completely corrupted. Is this situation avoidable?

node.title: how to get a component of the applied shear stress
node.bodyText:
I need the first component of the applied shear stress and its type is MaterialProperty<std::vector<Real>> as I see in CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate. Then, I need to finally compute the element's average value in the postprocessor. I learned that the AuxKernel MaterialRealVectorValueAux is what I need. But I got the error:
The following error occurred in the object "shear_stress0", of type "MaterialRealVectorValueAux".

The requested non-AD material property 'uncracked_applied_shear_stress' of type 'libMesh::VectorValue<double>'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'std::vector<double>' 

I know this is because of different type as std::vector<Real> instead of libMesh::VectorValue<double>. But how can I fix this? Or I must write my own auxkernel?

Hello
just prefix the auxkernel withAD to use the AD version

thanks for your reply. But I still got the error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "shear_stress0", of type "ADMaterialRealVectorValueAux".

The requested AD material property 'uncracked_applied_shear_stress' of type` 'libMesh::VectorValue<double>'`
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type `'std::vector<double>`'

I think the reason is MaterialRealVectorValueAux and ADMaterialRealVectorValueAux only support 'libMesh::VectorValue<double>'. And I checked the source code and this is indeed the case.
I tried many methods and all failed. This is not a difficult task but it is so hard to do in MOOSE......
Sounds like the material is a vector in the c++ container sense, not a vector in the mathematical sense. You should use MaterialStdVectorAux instead of MaterialRealVectorAux
thanks!

node.title: Tests failing after compilation and generation of executable in an HPC system
node.bodyText:
run_tests_log.txt
I am trying to run MOOSE on an HPC system. I have finished the installation process as per the documentation and generated the run_tests executable in the test folder in moose. However, when I run the tests, only 2 are successful and the rest fail.
I am attaching the output log of the run as a txt file herewith.
One of the errors that I see here (and also when I submit specific jobs using an example input file) is that the parameters mentioned in the input files are supplied twice.
For instance,
/misc/check_error/bad_kernel_var_test.i:41.5: parameter 'BCs/DirichletBC_type/boundary' supplied multiple times
I was wondering if anyone has come across this issue before or knows how to resolve it. Any help would be much appreciated.

@arjunvarmar -
I see from looking at your test output log that the problem is your WASP package has an incorrect configuration.
Specifically, the DISABLE_HIT_TYPE_PROMOTION CMake variable is turned off for your WASP build when it should be turned on.
Are you building MOOSE by using the pre-built Conda packages for WASP (and libMesh and PETSc)?
Or are you building your own WASP by using the scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh script?

@arjunvarmar -
I missed where you said this is a HPC system, so I assume you are building your own WASP and not using the Conda build.
Are you calling the scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh script to build WASP?
This script should use a configuration that turns on DISABLE_HIT_TYPE_PROMOTION, but that is not what your failures show.
Thanks a lot for that input. I was trying to use a pre-built module of WASP. When I used the scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh build instead, the tests ran fine! Thanks again.

node.title: Using the VectorNeumannBC
node.bodyText:
I am attempting to use the VectorNeumannBC with the vector velocity. I get the following error:
No standard variable named velocity found. Did you specify a vector variable when you meant to specify a standard variable?
Is it possible to use VectorNeumannBC with the NS variable velocity?

Which NS? INSAD or INSFE?
VectorNeumannBC is actually not for vector variables
For NS applications you ll have more specific BCs
@GiudGiud INSAD. I'm looking the implement the Directional Do Nothing BC.
You want to look at ADVectorFunctionNeumannBC.  This bit me before too!

node.title: Solving Eigenvalue problem for a square plate with a circular hole
node.bodyText:
I am trying to solve the eigenvalue problem for a square plate with a hole using the XFEM and level set modules. I checked out a few examples on the MOOSE repository for both modules and setup an input file for the same. I am getting some output but I am unable to see the circular hole or any change in eigenvalues. The following is the input file I am using
[GlobalParams]
    displacements = 'ux uy'
[]  

[XFEM]
    geometric_cut_userobjects = 'cut_mesh'
    qrule = volfrac
    output_cut_plane = true
[]
  

[Mesh]
    [First]
        type = FileMeshGenerator
        file = square.msh
    []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
    [./all]
      strain = SMALL
      planar_formulation = PLANE_STRAIN
      add_variables = true
      generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_yy stress_zz strain_xx strain_xy strain_yy strain_zz'
    [../]
[]
  

[UserObjects]
    [cut_mesh]
      type = InterfaceMeshCut2DUserObject
      mesh_file = circle_surface.e
      interface_velocity_function = vel_func
      #heal_always = true
    []
[]

[Functions]
    [vel_func]
      type = ConstantFunction
      value = 0
    []
[]

[AuxVariables]
    [ls]
      order = FIRST
      family = LAGRANGE
    []
[]  

[Kernels]
    [eigen1]
        type = CoefReaction
        variable = ux
        coefficient = -1.0
        extra_vector_tags = 'eigen'
    []

    [eigen2]
        type = CoefReaction
        variable = uy
        coefficient = -1.0
        extra_vector_tags = 'eigen'
    []
[]

[AuxKernels]
    [ls]
      type = MeshCutLevelSetAux
      mesh_cut_user_object = cut_mesh
      variable = ls
      execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
    []
  []
  

[BCs]
    [fixed1]
        type = DirichletBC
        variable = ux
        boundary = 'boundary'
        value = 0
    []
    [fixed2]
        type = DirichletBC
        variable = uy
        boundary = 'boundary'
        value = 0
    []

[]

[Materials]
    [./linear_stress]
        type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    [../]
    [./elasticity_tensor]
        type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
        poissons_ratio = 0.3
        youngs_modulus = 1e10
    [../]
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
    [eigen]
      type = Eigenvalues
      inverse_eigenvalue = true
    []
[]
  
#[Postprocessors]
#    [fluxintegral]
#      type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
#      variable = u
#      execute_on = linear
#    []
#[]

[Problem]
    type = EigenProblem
[]

#Linear  eigenvalue solver
[Executioner]
    type = Eigenvalue
    solve_type = arnoldi
    n_eigen_pairs = 4
[]

[Outputs]
    file_base =  eigen_circularhole_out
    exodus =  true
    csv = true
[]

Hello
I just run your case with a couple meshes that have the same name that I found in the moose folder and I immediately hit this error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "cut_mesh", of type "InterfaceMeshCut2DUserObject".

cutFragmentByGeometry not yet implemented for InterfaceMeshCut2DUserObject

so it seems there is some development work to do on this first.
Guillaume

Oh damn! Will look into the codes and get back to you with more questions. The moose examples have bimaterial interface but none with a hole. I was thinking I'll use it and use zero Young's modulus and poisson's ratio and try but yeah will see what I can do.

I tried two things

I used the LevelSetCutUserObject in MOOSE to specify the circular hole using equation $x^2  + y^2 - 25 = 0 $. I used the same square mesh. Some of the input files given as example  had a bimaterial interface. So I used it to change the materials properties to 0 (very close to zero) to see if it'll work. When I use ADTypeproperty, I got mismatch between AD and non-AD property.  When I changed it to nonAD type material  and strains I am getting this error

The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "EigenProblem".

Material property 'Jacobian_mult', requested by 'TM_TensorMechanics0' is not defined on block 1
Material property 'Jacobian_mult', requested by 'TM_TensorMechanics1' is not defined on block 1

How can one mention subdomain when there  is a square and hole in the center ?

I copied one of the examples  of bimaterial from xfem module and changed the executioner and kernel to see if the eigenvalue problem can be coupled with xfem. Ran into this error

The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "EigenProblem".

A libMesh::PetscSolverException was raised during FEProblemBase::computeJacobianTags
New nonzero at (0,0) caused a malloc
Use MatSetOption(A, MAT_NEW_NONZERO_ALLOCATION_ERR, PETSC_FALSE) to turn off this check

I have  added the input files in the github repo in the files titled eigen2d_xfem_trial2.i and eigen2d_xfem_trial3.i

How can one mention subdomain when there is a square and hole in the center ?

the hole is not meshed right? So you dont need to worry about defining a material there
what is block 1 in the mesh?

I copied one of the examples of bimaterial from xfem module and changed the executioner and kernel to see if the eigenvalue problem can be coupled with xfem. Ran into this error

see other thread. You can allow these re-allocations, which are due to XFEM

There is no hole. When the level set module represents a circle, the phantom nodes are created differentiating between the two domains and hence two materials. All the other examples I found in xfem rated to solid mechanics are related to crack propagation. This is the only thing I thought might work.
Will check out the other threads
ok then define the materials in all the blocks that the equations are defined on. If some equations should not be defined in the hole, then block restrict the kernels or the variables

node.title: Difference between JunctionOneToOne1Phase and VolumeJunction1Phase
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I would like to know the difference between JunctionOneToOne1Phase and VolumeJunction1Phase in THM.
If the simulation is Pipe1-Junction-Pipe2, I think the result using these two junction types should be the same. But I tested it using a lax_shock_tube test, the result is not the same. What's the reason?
lax_shock_tube_OnetoOne.txt
lax_shock_tube_VolumeBranch.txt
Result:

@joshuahansel
it looks to me like the junctions arent exactly at the same locations
It is truly at the same location, please see the input file. The discontinuity of JunctionOneToOne1Phase's result is caused by the shock tube, not the junction.

One difference between the two is that the volume junction doesn't do any slope reconstruction across the junction (maybe it could after some development? 🤔 ). So first compare them both with rdg_slope_reconstruction = none. The differences in the results are quite striking though, so I'd be surprised if that were everything.
I think the main reason may be the volume you've chosen does not yield an equivalent problem. You have A = 1 and volume = 1, so it's like you're junction is actually L = volume / A = 1 long, twice the length of each of the pipes. For an equivalent problem, probably choose the volume to give you an element length. Then take away one element from one of the connected pipes. Then you probably need to shift the ICs by a half element. Make sense? You basically want to replace one of the elements from the one-to-one junction case with this volume junction.
I got it! Thanks a lot! I use rdg_slope_reconstruction = none for these two cases, but it still has a little difference. What's the reason?
And did you try what I said in the second paragraph too? If so, please supply input files again.

Yes, I changed volume=_element_lenth * _A = 0.01. Here are the input files.
lax_shock_tube_VolumeBranch.txt
lax_shock_tube_OnetoOne.txt
It appears you didn't do the element deletion I talked about: For your volume junction input file, shorten the length and number of elements of the right channel by 1 element.
What's happening is that your volume junction case has additional length that is not captured in your plot.
I understand it! Thanks a lot!

node.title: Couple diffusion and cohesive models
node.bodyText:
Hi @GiudGiud , @arovinelli :
I want to couple the concentration of a diffusion problem with the cohesive zone model:
For this I want to do something like this:
Say my Diffusion variable is c
[Kernels]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = c
[]

THe couple statement is:
In [Materials]
If c>c0
CZM is
  type = TractionLaw1
  boundary = 'interface'
  normal_stiffness = 100*(1-c)
  tangent_stiffness = 100
 normal_jump = 1*(1-c)
  tangentjump = 100
[../]

else
  type = TractionLaw2
  boundary = 'interface'
  normal_stiffness = 200*(1+c)
  tangent_stiffness = 200
 normal_jump = 1*(1+c)
  tangentjump = 100
[../]

Please suggest incorporating if-else in choosing materials property and coupling cohesive models.

Hello
Make a 3rd material property that incorporates this if-else condition
OR
combine 1&2 in a single property to be able to host the if-else there

Hi @GiudGiud , I tried finding for an example in the MOOSE directory that could help me sort things but could not, can you please suggest one.
Please suggest?
I was thinking of new .C and .h files but ADParsedMaterial should work too!

Hi @GiudGiud , @arovinelli ,I got this error:
*** ERROR ***
/Users/sidharthsarmah/MOOSE/projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/CZM/Block/elastic.i:182: invalid float syntax for parameter: Materials/czm/maximum_normal_traction=stiff
/Users/sidharthsarmah/MOOSE/projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/CZM/Block/elastic.i:183: invalid float syntax for parameter: Materials/czm/normal_gap_at_maximum_normal_traction=jump

you need to change the valid param I think
it s expecting floats for these parameters

@GiudGiud , this is what I want to achieve.

I have two different traction laws, TSL1 and TSL2 for the cohesive models.
Based on the variable cL values,

[Kernels]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = cL
[]

I want either of the TSL to execute.
[Materials]

      if (cL >0.5)
            [./TSL1]
            type = TractionLaw1
            boundary = 'interface'
            normal_stiffness = 100(1-cL)
            tangent_stiffness = 10
           normal_jump = 1(1-cL)
            tangentjump = 10
          [../]

      else 
  [./TSL2]
            type = TractionLaw2
            boundary = 'interface'
            normal_stiffness = 200(1+cL)
            tangent_stiffness = 10
           normal_jump = 2*(1+cL)
            tangentjump = 10
   [../]

Can you suggest any example in MOOSE, or which object I need to use for this?

I think the ParsedMaterial route should have worked.
What did you try in the input?

Hi @GiudGiud , no the conditional on cL does not come into play to switch the material properties, could you suggest something.

  [./CZM_stiffness]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = stiffness
    coupled_variables = 'cL'
    expression = 'if(cL>0.5, 1500*(1-cL), 500'
    material_property_names = 'Q    R	T'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./CZM_jump]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = jump
    coupled_variables = 'cL'
    expression = 'if(cL >0.5, 0.25*(1-cL), 0.1'
    material_property_names = 'Q    R	T'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./TSL1]
    type = Traction1
    boundary = 'interface'
    maximum_normal_traction = stiffness
    normal_gap_at_maximum_normal_traction = jump
    maximum_shear_traction = 1
    tangential_gap_at_maximum_shear_traction = 0.2
  [../]

  [./TSL2]
    type = Traction2
    boundary = 'interface'
    maximum_normal_traction = stiffness
    normal_gap_at_maximum_normal_traction = jump
    maximum_shear_traction = 1
    tangential_gap_at_maximum_shear_traction = 0.2
  [../]
[]

Is there anything like this:
 expression = 'if(cL >0.5, TSL1 (T0=100*(1-cL), d0=0.25*(1-cL)), TSL2(T0=100*(1+cL), d0=0.25*(1+cL))' instead?

The syntax of the conditions is not right, you need to move that last parenthesis.
The TSL, have many material properties do they define? And what name do they use for these properties?
You ll have to define a new name for each in the ParsedMaterial(s) and then use that new name in the rest of the input file

Hi @GiudGiud , I did not get it.
I corrected expression = 'if(cL>0.5, 1500*(1-cL), 500)
The TSL have 3 max tractions (1 normal and 2 shear) and 3 max jumps (1 normal and 2 shear)
say the TSLS are
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/cohesive_zone_model/SalehaniIrani3DCTraction.html.
and
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/cohesive_zone_model/PureElasticTractionSeparation.html.
Can you suggest even if I name one new input, how will I restrict one of the TSL from being active based on cL?
They are both active and compute a value but it s the ParsedMaterial that makes the selection of the value based on the conditional evaluation and provides the value to the consumer objects

Hi @GiudGiud , I want to add a rate dependent term to the traction law as indicated in red:

Step 1: Define parameter nu in .h, 'const ADMaterialProperty & _nu;':
Please suggest, also if Steps 1 and 2 are correct.

hello
you could try using the old material prioperty and the current one and forming the time derivative by dividing the difference by _dt
(mat - mat_old) / dt
Use getMaterialPropertyOld to get the old material property. No need to use AD
Guillaume
Hi @GiudGiud , is this correct:

You're doing old minus current
Is this intended? Eg are you propagation a minus sign from elsewhere?

Hi @GiudGiud , its : current - old:
 traction_local(i) = viscosity*(_max_allowable_traction(i)/_delta_u0(i))*((_interface_displacement_jump[_qp] - _interface_displacement_jump_old[_qp])/_dt);

Hi @GiudGiud , so this is what I did:

Define new parameters in .h files, Can I define it this way even though the _interface_displacement_jump_old is a vector in 3D:

Hello
This is an easy one to fix. It says right in the error message.
You need to order initializations in the constructor initialiser list the same way that they are ordered in the header
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud thanks, but my doubt is, the Max traction and displacement are vector value, it is correct to store their old values as material property?
ScheiderViscous::ScheiderViscous(const InputParameters & parameters)
  : CZMComputeLocalTractionTotalBase(parameters),
   
 _delta_u0({getParam<Real>("normal_gap_at_maximum_normal_traction"),
               getParam<Real>("tangential_gap_at_maximum_shear_traction"),
               getParam<Real>("tangential_gap_at_maximum_shear_traction")}),
   
 _max_allowable_traction({getParam<Real>("maximum_normal_traction"),
                             getParam<Real>("maximum_shear_traction"),
                             getParam<Real>("maximum_shear_traction")}),
    
_interface_displacement_jump_old(
    getMaterialPropertyOld<RealVectorValue>(_base_name + "interface_displacement_jump")),

The interface displacement is a vector in your code now.
Are delta_u and max_traction supposed to be vectors? They are Real in this code.
In general there are no issues with working a vector material property, with its current and old values.

HI @GiudGiud, thanks:
I still think there is some issue as there was no convergence, could you please check:

.h:

in 4., this math for the tracition separation derivative doesnt look right.
you can only exchange the derivatives if the second derivatives are continuous (Schwarz theorem).
Then it looks like you are simplifying the 'd' away for the old term.
I would redo the last step of the derivation in 4 by approximating with the forward Euler time derivative the (delta - delta_old)/d_delta term

node.title: Questions about the NS module
node.bodyText:
@GiudGiud Hello guys, I know that the Reactor module can create complex geometry meshes that are related to reactors. Can I use the NS module on the mesh which is created by the Reactor module?
Ethan

Hello
Yes but you'll want to keep the number of elements down until we merge the scalable solver.
Guillaume
We have scalable solvers for moderate Reynolds number for finite elements

node.title: How to set boundary conditions
node.bodyText:
Hi，
I am simulating the shear process of the soil, but when there is a deviating stress, it creates a very large horizontal displacement, which is not normal. What is the reason for this? I set the boundary conditions as follows:
[Functions]
  [zhouya]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 3600 10800 21600'
    y = '0 5e5  5e5   1e6'
  []
  [weiya]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 3600 10800 21600'
    y = '0 5e5  5e5  5e5'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [Pressure]
    [load1]
      boundary = 'upface'
      function = zhouya
    []
    [load2]
      boundary = 'boundface'
      function = weiya
    []
  []

  [no_z_disp_at_bottom]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
    boundary = 'downface'
  []

  [topdrained]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = porepressure
    value = 0
    boundary = 'upface'
  []
[]

Thanks for your help.
How many dimensions is your problem?  I only see a bc set on disp_z.

node.title: Frequency domain analysis - two materials
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE users,
I am trying to modify the input script that performs a frequency-domain analysis of a cantilever to have it accept several materials. The source example is here:
modules/solid_mechanics/examples/wave_propagation/cantilever_sweep.i
I am reading a mesh from an exodus file where blocks were already pre-defined (blocks 1, 2, ... N). I would like to assign material properties based on the block definitions. The elastic properties is easy and having N snippets like this one works:
  [elastic_tensor_Al]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 68e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.36
    block = 1
  []

But I still haven't found a way to define densities based on block definitions. Density is provided in:
[Functions]
  [./freq2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    symbol_names = density
    symbol_values = 2.7e3 #Al kg/m3
    expression = '-t * t * density'
  [../]
[]

ParsedFunction does not accept a 'block' argument. I tried using variations of if-else statements, like " expression = if(block==1,'freq1' ,if(block==2, 'freq2', 'freq3')) ". I tried for expression and symbol_names/symbol_values but unsuccessfully.
Any ideas?
Many thanks.
Luca

Hello
Functions are global and predefined functions of space and time. They cannot be block restricted.
What object type of the freq123?
Same question for t and density ?
If they are not functions or postprocessors, they cannot be used here. You ll have to use a ParsedMaterial. (Which can be block restricted)
guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thanks for your reply. So copying from the original example in https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/solid_mechanics/1d_elastic_waves.html :
[Functions]
  [./freq2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    symbol_names = density
    symbol_values = 2.7e3 #Al kg/m3
    expression = '-t * t * density'
  [../]
[]

[Controls]
  [./func_control]
    type = RealFunctionControl
    parameter = 'Kernels/*/rate'
    function = 'freq2'
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_begin'
  [../]
[]

From here I understand that freq2 is of type FunctionName and density is the name (string) of a variable to which value 2700 is assigned inside the definition of freq2. t is time. This input file was among the examples provided in the solid_mechanics/examples folder. All I need to do is to specify -- based on blocks defined in the ingested mesh -- two different densities. So, if you like, it would be finding the resonances of a bilayered beam of say aluminium (say block = 1) and steel (say block = 2).
Since RealFunctionControl takes a function as parameter I cannot specify a ParsedMaterial instead of ParsedFunction, unless there's a workaround (?)
Thanks!
Luca

Ok this is fine if t = time and density is a constant.
The function will only be sampled at point 0,0,0 in a Control, so there's no point block restricting it.
Maybe you should have multiple kernels, one for each block, and use one Control for each kernel
This suggestion of multiple kernels and controls worked like a charm. Thanks!
